docs.lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton just gave a rousing speech at a fall luncheon of female Democrats in midtown Manhattan, urging them to help elect a Democratic Congress to insure "the president and vice president are not above the law."

docs.lead_paragraph: Tomorrow in Chappaqua, Hillary Rodham Clinton will meet with Ned Lamont, the Greenwich businessman who aspires to join her in the Senate. We're told they will talk about ways she can be helpful to Mr. Lamont's campaign to unseat Senator Joseph I. Lieberman. Will she raise money for him, campaign by his side (as her husband did for Mr. Lieberman during the primary) or maybe just offer political savvy? Tomorrow will tell.
docs.abstract: Senator Hillary Clinton will meet with Ned Lamont to discuss how she can help his senate campaign.
docs.snippet: Senator Hillary Clinton will meet with Ned Lamont to discuss how she can help his senate campaign....

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Hillary Rodham Clinton's rejection of political contributions from the American Muslim Alliance (front page, Oct. 27) is the most shameless form of pandering, not to mention hypocrisy, coming as it does from a person who prides herself on being a supporter of equal rights for people of all races and faiths.

docs.lead_paragraph: A defense lawyer in the second Whitewater trial raised the possibility today of calling Hillary Rodham Clinton as a witness and compelling her first public testimony in the matter. But the lawyer later backed off, saying it probably would not happen. The lawyer, Dan Guthrie, who represents one of two Arkansas bankers on trial, suggested calling Mrs. Clinton after prosecutors were allowed to introduce evidence about $180,000 in personal loans that Bill Clinton and his wife received from an Arkansas bank in connection with Mr. Clinton's 1990 campaign for governor.

docs.lead_paragraph: It is the end of Hillary Rodham Clinton's first year in office. That description alone illustrates how successful she has been at transforming the notion of how the spouse of the President can serve the nation. Amid endless speculation about how much she could do and how openly she could do it, Mrs. Clinton simply went to work on health care reform. When the President introduced his plan to the Congress, she was applauded enthusiastically. Polls suggest the American people applauded, too.

docs.lead_paragraph: Arthur J. Hillary, who was business manager of Brooklyn College for 21 years until he retired last November, died on Friday at Memorial Hospital after a short illness. He was 73 years old and lived at 151 East 83d Street.
